 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today but no episodes of sinus
   pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - f/u heme/onc on need for neupogen
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with small cell lung carcinoma, complicated by SVC syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. Her respiratory status has deteriorated, with increased RR and decreased PaO2. She has developed hypoxic respiratory failure, with a high risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Her electrolyte profile is abnormal, with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. She has also developed anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, and she is at high risk of developing VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis may be indicative of sepsis.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis may be indicative of adrenal insufficiency.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte profile is abnormal, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is deteriorating, which may lead to respiratory failure.
6. Sepsis-induced acute kidney injury: The patient's metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia may be indicative of sepsis-induced acute kidney injury.
7. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may lead to cardiac tamponade and cardiac arrest.
8. Malignant effusion: The patient's pleural effusion may be malignant, which may lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Administer antibiotics to prevent VAP.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte profile closely and adjust fluid and electrolyte replacement as necessary.
4. Consider administering corticosteroids to treat adrenal insufficiency.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including ECG and echocardiogram.
6. Consider administering diuretics to treat pericardial effusion.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusion and consider thoracentesis or pleurodesis if necessary.
8. Consider administering chemotherapy and radiation therapy to treat the patient's small cell lung carcinoma.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. He is mechanically ventilated and sedated. The patient has a history of COPD and has developed new RLL and LLL infiltrates, which are concerning for pneumonitis (VAP). He is receiving empirical antimicrobials and is being monitored for sputum culture. The patient has also developed a right pleural effusion, which has been resolved with chest tube drainage, and a right pneumothorax, which is being managed with a chest tube. He is demonstrating a clinical response to XRT and chemotherapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on background of COPD.
2. Pneumonitis (VAP): The patient's new RLL and LLL infiltrates are concerning for pneumonitis (VAP), which can lead to further respiratory failure and worsening of his condition.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's rising creatinine and falling urine output suggest possible pre-renal failure, which can be exacerbated by chemotherapy agents.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being monitored, and his blood pressure is being maintained at 140-160 mmHg.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is attributed to adrenal insufficiency, hypodalosternism, and SIADH, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
6. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is resolving, but could be secondary to RTA due to hypoaldosteronism, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
7. Sinus Dysrhythmia: The patient's sinus pauses are being monitored, and a cardiology consultation is in progress to determine the cause of his sinus dysrhythmia.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, but could worsen if not managed properly.
9. Nutritional Support: The patient is NPO, and consideration is being given to providing total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to support his nutritional needs.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve his condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with small cell lung carcinoma, complicated by SVC syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Her condition has worsened over the past 24 hours, with increased respiratory acidosis, metabolic acidosis, and hyperkalemia. She has also developed a pneumothorax, which has resolved, and a pericardial effusion, which is suspected to be malignant.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's increased respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis suggest that VAP is a possibility.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's persistent metabolic acidosis may be due to hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA, which could worsen her condition if left untreated.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may be due to hypoaldosteronism, and if left untreated, could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and even cardiac arrest.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is suspected to be malignant, and if left untreated, could lead to cardiac tamponade and even death.
5. Pneumothorax: Although the patient's pneumothorax has resolved, there is a risk of recurrence if the chest tube is removed too soon.
6. SVC syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome is a concern, as it could lead to further worsening of her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
7. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) suggest that she may have an underlying infection, which could worsen her condition if left untreated.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to chronic disease or blood loss, and if left untreated, could lead to further worsening of her cardiovascular status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status closely, and adjust her ventilator settings and medications as necessary.
2. Treat the patient's metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy and consider consulting endocrinology for further guidance.
3. Monitor the patient's hyperkalemia and adjust her potassium levels as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and consider consulting cardiology for further guidance.
5. Monitor the patient's pneumothorax and chest tube placement, and remove the tube only when necessary.
6. Consider consulting infectious disease for further guidance on the patient's suspected VAP.
7. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider consulting hematology for further guidance.
8. Consider consulting neurology for further guidance on the patient's mental status and potential cerebral aneurysm repair.

   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right

s vagally mediated.  Pauses

   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from

   .

   .

   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She was admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's condition has been unstable, with concerns about hypoxic respiratory failure, sinus pause, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hyponatremia.

The patient's renal function is deteriorating, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 19 mg/dL. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 5.3 mEq/L and a sodium level of 140 mEq/L.

The patient's respiratory status is also concerning, with a respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 145 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also concerning, with a heart rate of 114 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 144/70 mmHg. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus tachycardia, and the patient has a pronounced S2 at the apex.

The patient's neurological status is also concerning, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. The patient's mental status is described as "sluggish," and the patient has a number of chronic changes on her head computed tomography (CT) scan.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and the patient's PaO2 is low. The patient may be at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and the patient has a fever. The patient may be at risk for sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus tachycardia, and the patient has a number of cardiac risk factors. The patient may be at risk for cardiac arrest.
4. Stroke: The patient's neurological status is concerning, and the patient has a number of risk factors for stroke. The patient may be at risk for stroke.
5. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient has a number of risk factors for bleeding. The patient may be at risk for bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and the patient has a fever. The patient may be at risk for infection.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and the patient may be at risk for electrolyte imbalance.
8. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient may be at risk for renal failure.
9. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion is concerning, and the patient may be at risk for cardiac tamponade.
10. SVC syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome is concerning, and the patient may be at risk for SVC syndrome.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust the patient's oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust the patient's cardiac medications as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust the patient's neurological medications as needed.

 alpha hemolytic colonies consistent with alpha strep or

 4+ GNR, 2+ budding yeast, 2+ GPC in pairs, chains, clusters
   Blood Cx

   Vanc level- 28
   .
   CXR
 The progressive interstitial pulmonary abnormality and right
   pleural effusion probably due to pulmonary edema. More severe
   consolidative abnormalities at both lung bases are also concerning for
   pneumonia. Right apical pleural tube in place. No pneumothorax. ET tube
   and nasogastric tube in standard placements. Heart size normal,
   unchanged. The bulk of the large right upper lobe mass has decreased
   over the past several days.
   [**8-26**] Pleural fluid path/cytology- Rare cells are highlighted by TTF-1;
   however, these cells are not cytologically atypical and may represent
   non-specific reactivity
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Continues to have mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis despite increasing RR yesterday.  Peak pressures
   in the high 38-40 and plat pressures of 30 last night so decreased TV
   and increased RR to maintain same MV of 12 but to decrease airway
   pressures. Pressure decreased slightly with these changes with plat of
   25.  Her oxygenation was worse last night with saturation decreased to
   91%.  Her PEEP was increased.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine to cover MRSA
   VAP
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Will need to touch base with heme/onc
   and rad/onc regarding plans for XRT or more chemo.
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   - IP checked Y stent placement on xray and looks the same, if continued
   problems with high pressures will consider future bronch
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol for almost 24
   hours and continues to not follow commands.  She does withdraw from
   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - started neupogen yesterday with plan for 10 day course
   - will discuss with heme/onc and rad/onc their plans for future
   chemo/radiation
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Suspect
   chemo is cause although prerenal as well based on FeNa of 0.3.  RTA may
   also play a role.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - f/u renal recs, plan to spin urine to look for sediment and casts
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - check vanc level
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved with Na 140 today. Unclear etiology on
   admission as appeared to be mixed picture of SIADH plus
   hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA.  However now thought by
   endocrine that pt was not adrenally insufficient or hypoaldo.  There
   may be some contribution of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney
   perfusion.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 150
   cc q4hrs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to Type IV RTA although unclear
   etiology.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   ICU Care

   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma, SVC syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She was admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's current condition is complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute renal failure, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, SVC syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, and pericardial effusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, which may lead to further respiratory decline if not managed properly.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to various causes, including seizure, toxic metabolic, infection, or progression of cancer. A repeat CT head and EEG may be necessary to evaluate for any changes.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may be caused by chemotherapy with carboplatin, and further management is needed to prevent worsening of renal function.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be due to a mixed picture of SIADH and hypoaldosteronism, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may be due to hypoaldosteronism, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
6. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be due to Type IV RTA, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
7. SVC Syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further respiratory and cardiovascular compromise.
8. Pleural Effusion: The patient's pleural effusion may be malignant, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
9. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax may recur if not managed properly, leading to further respiratory compromise.
10. Pericardial Effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may be malignant, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory status with increased RR and PEEP to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Repeat the patient's CT head and EEG to evaluate for any changes in mental status.
3. Further evaluate the patient's acute renal failure with a renal ultrasound and consider further management with dialysis.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's SVC syndrome with radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
6. Monitor the patient's pleural effusion and consider further evaluation with a thoracentesis.
7. Monitor the patient's pneumothorax and consider further evaluation with a chest X-ray.
8. Monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and consider further evaluation with an echocardiogram.
9. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with hydralazine and monitor the patient's blood pressure closely.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider further evaluation with a neurology consultation if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yof with new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma  with SVC syndrome
   (partial compression), airway compromise (requiring Y-stent).
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 multifactorisl, primarily due to extrinsic and
   intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on
   background of COPD(?).  Also evidence for new RLL and LLL
   (retrocardiac) infiltrates, concerning for pneumonai (VAP) -->
   empirical antimicrobials.  Continue mechanical ventilation, montior
   ABG.  Monitor sputum, await culture.  Hope to eventually work towards
   SBT and extubation once completes VAP treatment and completes chemoRx
   and XRT.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES -- RLL > LLL --> attributed to VAP.  Now on
   antimicrobials.  Monitor.
   MENTAL STATUS
 very slow to awken, now off Propofol >24 hrs.  Repeat
   head CT unrevealing for new pathology.  MRI not possible due to
   presence of intracranial surgical clips.  Underlying seizure disorder
   (on kepra) --> Plan EEG (continuous) to assess for non-convulsive
   status epilepticus.  LP for CSF analysis (concern for carcinomatous
   meningitis).  Consider Neurological Consultation.  [**Month (only) 11**] be toxic
   metabolic.
   SVC SYNDROME -- much improved over past 48 hrs.  Completed
   chemotherapy, continue XRT.
   RIGHT PLEURAL EFFUSION -- resolved, s/p chest tube drainage.
   Malignant.  Chest tube now removed.
   RIGHT PNEUMOTHORAX -- chest tube remains in place, lung fully
   expanded.  No evidence for air leak.
   SMALL CELL CA -- demonstating clinical response to XRT and
   chemotherapy.   Radiation Oncology and Oncology services involve
   appreciate recommendations and guidance.  Monitor for tumor lysis.
   Need to better define prognosis.
   PERICARDIAL EFFUSION -- no evidence of tamponade on exam
 continue to
   monitor.
   HYPONATREMIA -- improved.  Attributed to adrenal insufficiency,
   hypaldosteronism, SIADH --> possibly a mixture.  Continue steroids.
   HYPERTENSION
 monitor BP.  Maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg
   FLUIDS -- positive fluid balance, likely related to chemotherapy
   agents.  However, appears pre-renal --> continue net hydration.
   Monitor I/O.
   RENAL FAILURE -- rising creatinine, falling urine output.  Possible
   pre-renal, possibly related to chemotherapy and recent contrast dye.
   Monitor urine output, BUN, creatinine.
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS  -- persistent, mild
 could be RTA secondary to
   hypoaldosteronism.  Continue to monitor.
   SEIZURE DISORDER -- continue kepra.  EEG to assess for non-convulsive
   status.
   SINUS DYSRHYTHMIA
 sinus pauses, no hemodynamic compromise.  Possible
   related to hilar mass, possible invovlement of conduction system.
   Possible vagal tone.  Monitor electrolytes.  Hold beta-blocker.
   Cardiology Consultation -- possible vagal response, and without need
   for specific intervention.
   ANEMIA -- stable, no evidence of hemolysis
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- TF.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a recent head CT scan showing no new pathology.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with multifactorial respiratory failure primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on background of COPD. There are also new RLL and LLL infiltrates, concerning for VAP. The patient is on empirical antimicrobials and is being monitored for sputum and culture.

The patient's mental status is slow to awaken, with a recent head CT scan showing no new pathology. The patient is off Propofol and is being monitored for non-convulsive status epilepticus. The patient is also at risk for carcinomatous meningitis and is undergoing an EEG and LP for CSF analysis.

The patient's SVC syndrome has improved over the past 48 hours, and chemotherapy and XRT have been completed. The patient's right pleural effusion has resolved, and the chest tube has been removed. The patient's right pneumothorax is being monitored, with a chest tube remaining in place.

The patient's small cell CA is demonstrating clinical response to XRT and chemotherapy, but the patient's prognosis is unclear. The patient is also at risk for tumor lysis and is being monitored.

The patient's pericardial effusion is not causing tamponade, but is being monitored. The patient's hypovolemia has improved, but is still being monitored. The patient's hypertension is being monitored, with a goal SBP of 140-160 mmHg.

The patient's fluid balance is positive, likely related to chemotherapy agents. The patient's renal function is declining, with rising creatinine and falling urine output. The patient's metabolic acidosis is persistent, and may be related to RTA secondary to hypoaldosteronism.

The patient's seizure disorder is being managed with Kepra, and an EEG is being performed to assess for non-convulsive status. The patient's sinus dysrhythmia is being monitored, with possible involvement of the conduction system.

The patient's anemia is stable, and nutritional support is being provided through a TF. The patient is critically ill and requires ongoing ICU care.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to VAP or worsening COPD
* Sepsis or septic shock due to VAP or other infections
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to sinus dysrhythmia or other cardiac conditions
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury due to chemotherapy or other medications
* Metabolic acidosis or alkalosis due to RTA or other metabolic disorders
* Tumor lysis syndrome due to chemotherapy or other medications
* Cerebral edema or other neurological complications due to carcinomatous meningitis or other neurological conditions
* Infection or sepsis due to immunocompromise
* Hypertension or hypotension due to medication or other medical conditions
* Fluid overload or dehydration due to chemotherapy or other medications
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to chemotherapy or other medications
* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to immunocompromise or other medical conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is receiving empirical antimicrobials for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with multifactorial causes of respiratory failure, including extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, and new retrocardiac infiltrates concerning for pneumonitis. The patient is also at risk for pulmonary infiltrates, which are attributed to VAP.

The patient's mental status is impaired, with a very slow awakening and a history of seizure disorder. The patient is off propofol and has undergone a repeat head CT without revealing any new pathology. The patient is being monitored for non-convulsive status epilepticus and is scheduled for an EEG and LP for CSF analysis.

The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, with a heart rate of 112 bpm and a blood pressure of 147/78 mmHg. The patient has a small pleural effusion, which has resolved, and a right pneumothorax, which is being monitored.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a rising creatinine and falling urine output. The patient is also at risk for metabolic acidosis, which could be related to hypoaldosteronism.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.3 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 2.5 mg/dL. The patient is being monitored for sinus dysrhythmia, which is thought to be related to the hilar mass and possible involvement of the conduction system.

The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with a total parenteral nutrition (TPN) order for 25 mL/hour. The patient is also at risk for anemia, which is stable and not related to hemolysis.

The patient's overall condition is critical, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and a high risk of mortality. The patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, and metabolic status.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Pneumonitis or pneumonitis-related respiratory failure
* VAP-related sepsis
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury
* Metabolic acidosis or alkalosis
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Sinus dysrhythmia or arrhythmia
* Seizure disorder or non-convulsive status epilepticus
* Anemia or bleeding
* Infection or sepsis
* Organ dysfunction or failure

The patient's treatment plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, antimicrobial therapy, and monitoring of their respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, and metabolic status. The patient is also scheduled for an EEG and LP for CSF analysis, and is being monitored for non-convulsive status epilepticus.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a poor mental status. He has received XRT and chemotherapy, and is currently undergoing treatment for VAP and pneumonitis. He has a history of COPD, seizure disorder, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 96%.
* Cardiovascular: sinus tachycardia, with a blood pressure of 147/78 mmHg.
* Neurological: sedated, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3.
* Renal: creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL, with a rising creatinine and falling urine output.
* Metabolic: hyperglycemia, with a blood glucose level of 160 mg/dL.
* Hematological: anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.7 g/dL.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: the patient is already intubated and mechanically ventilated, but there is a risk of further respiratory compromise due to his underlying lung disease and the presence of VAP.
* Sepsis: the patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of VAP.
* Renal failure: the patient's creatinine level is rising, and he has a history of chemotherapy and contrast dye exposure, which may have contributed to his renal failure.
* Metabolic acidosis: the patient has a persistent mild metabolic acidosis, which may be related to his underlying disease or treatment.
* Seizure disorder: the patient has a history of seizure disorder and is currently on kepra, but there is a risk of non-convulsive status epilepticus.
* Hypertension: the patient's blood pressure is elevated, and there is a risk of further hypertension due to his underlying disease and treatment.

Assessment and plan:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor ABG.
* Monitor sputum and await culture.
* Continue antimicrobials for VAP.
* Monitor for tumor lysis and better define prognosis.
* Continue steroids for adrenal insufficiency and hypoadrenalism.
* Monitor I/O and electrolytes.
* Hold beta-blocker for sinus dysrhythmia.
* Consider Neurological Consultation for seizure disorder.
* Continue kepra for seizure disorder.
* Monitor for non-convulsive status epilepticus.
* Consider Cardiology Consultation for sinus dysrhythmia.
* Continue nutritional support with TF.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and take prompt action if necessary.

   .

 4+ GNR, 2+ budding yeast, 2+ GPC in pairs, chains, clusters
   Blood Cx
 pending
   Vanc level- 34.4
   Granulocyte count- 790
   .
   CXR: No change in RUL mass; slight interval improvement in R basal
   consolidation
   CT head: No change from [**2172-8-28**].
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   ICU Care

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure, and her respiratory status is complicated by possible underlying COPD, air stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, and atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases. 2. Infection: The patient has a history of VAP and is at risk of developing further infections, particularly given her immunocompromised state and presence of central lines and catheters.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and she has a history of carboplatin chemotherapy, which can cause renal toxicity. The patient's renal function may continue to deteriorate, leading to acute renal failure.
4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has a metabolic acidosis, which may worsen if her renal function continues to deteriorate or if she develops further complications.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may recur if her sodium levels are not closely monitored and managed.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may persist or worsen if her potassium levels are not closely monitored and managed.
7. SVC Syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome may recur or worsen if her SVC is not properly decompressed.
8. Pleural Effusion: The patient's pleural effusion may recur or worsen if her effusion is not properly managed.
9. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax may recur or worsen if her lung is not properly decompressed.
10. Pericardial Effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may recur or worsen if her effusion is not properly managed.
11. Sinus Pause: The patient's sinus pause may recur or worsen if her heart rate is not properly managed.
12. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may persist or worsen if her white blood cell count is not closely monitored and managed.
13. Anemia: The patient's anemia may persist or worsen if her hematocrit is not closely monitored and managed.
14. Cerebral Aneurysm: The patient's cerebral aneurysm may recur or worsen if her aneurysm is not properly managed.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Continues to have mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis despite increasing RR yesterday.  Peak pressures
   in the high 38-40 and plat pressures of 30 last night so decreased TV
   and increased RR to maintain same MV of 12 but to decrease airway
   pressures. Pressure decreased slightly with these changes with plat of
   25.  Her oxygenation was worse last night with saturation decreased to
   91%.  Her PEEP was increased.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine to cover MRSA
   VAP
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Will need to touch base with heme/onc
   and rad/onc regarding plans for XRT or more chemo.
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   - IP checked Y stent placement on xray and looks the same, if continued
   problems with high pressures will consider future bronch
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol for almost 24
   hours and continues to not follow commands.  She does withdraw from
   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT. -RAD ONC:
   Discussing with Med Onc, Don't know when Med Onc plans to give more
   chemo. Initially, XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated
   lots of nl tissue; needs formal tissue planning session to reduce
   amount they radiate; will wait until new scans/doing clinically better;
   Will do formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a
   bit. Small cell is responsive to chemo so hoping this will shrink so
   they can irradiate less and preserve more nl tissue.  -HEM/ONC: Chemo
   completed. Will be a few weeks before next round.
   - started neupogen yesterday with plan for 10 day course
   - will discuss with heme/onc and rad/onc their plans for future
   chemo/radiation
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Suspect
   chemo is cause although prerenal as well based on FeNa of 0.3.  RTA may
   also play a role.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - f/u renal recs, plan to spin urine to look for sediment and casts
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - check vanc level
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved with Na 140 today.  Not Type IV RTA b/c urine
   sodium not >30 (If RTA Type IV, SC Heparin can cause this). Most likely
   ATN [**2-10**] hypoperfusion. Low UNa does not exclude SIADH (REc: recheck
   urine lytes with saline load- in SIADH, UNa should increase and Uosm
   should remain high), optimize BP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep
   increased intravascular delivery to kidneys, check serum renin,
   aldosterone. Check renal US  for obstruction (ordered).
   Unclear etiology on admission as appeared to be mixed picture of SIADH
   plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA.  However now thought by
   endocrine that pt was not adrenally insufficient or hypoaldo.  There
   may be some contribution of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney
   perfusion.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 150
   cc q4hrs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  -Acid/Base: so, looking at her ABG, she has a
   respiratory acidosis and a gap metabolic acidosis (which is why her pH
   is lower than you'd expect from either process alone). SO, up to this
   point, we've been saying her metabolic acidosis is non-gap and
   attributed to Type IV RTA (she may have been non-gap, or we may not
   have calculated it properly given her albumin). BUT, our differential
   is now MUDPILES. Her metabolic acidosis may be due to her uremia.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol

   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid

Based on the daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient continues to have mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis despite increasing respiratory rate. The patient's oxygenation worsened last night, and PEEP was increased.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has been off propofol for almost 24 hours and continues to not follow commands. The differential diagnosis includes seizure, toxic metabolic, infection, and progression of cancer.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient is suspected to have chemo-induced acute renal failure.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level has resolved, but the etiology is unclear.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, and the etiology is unclear.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a gap metabolic acidosis, which may be due to uremia.
7. SVC syndrome: The patient has incomplete occlusion of the superior vena cava and brachiocephalic veins, which has improved edema on examination.
8. Pleural effusion: The patient had a right pigtail catheter placement, which was removed, and the effusion was exudative.
9. Pneumothorax: The patient had a pneumothorax, which appears to be resolved.
10. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a suspected malignant effusion.
11. Sinus pause on telemetry: The patient had episodes of sinus pauses on telemetry, which are thought to be vagally mediated.
12. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is trending downwards possibly due to chemotherapy.
13. Anemia: The patient has normocytic anemia, and the acute concern is disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
14. Hypertension: The patient remains hypertensive despite holding metoprolol.

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and chemotherapeutic agents. The patient is also receiving nutritional support through a nasogastric tube.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, potassium, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, including hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head, chest, and pelvis, show a mass in the right upper lobe of the lung, which is consistent with small cell lung carcinoma. The patient's CT scan also shows a pericardial effusion and a pneumothorax.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
2. Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjusting ventilator settings as needed.
3. Managing the patient's electrolyte disturbances, including hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.
4. Monitoring the patient's renal function and adjusting medication dosages accordingly.
5. Managing the patient's hypertension and arrhythmias.
6. Monitoring the patient's mental status and adjusting medication dosages accordingly.
7. Performing regular neuroimaging studies to monitor the patient's brain function.
8. Monitoring the patient's white blood cell count and adjusting chemotherapy dosages accordingly.
9. Providing nutritional support through a nasogastric tube.
10. Managing the patient's pericardial effusion and pneumothorax.

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient is currently in the ICU for further management.

   58 yof with new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma  with SVC syndrome

   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 multifactorial, malpositioning/migration of ETT
   between stent and tracheal wall.  Also underlying extrinsic and
   intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on
   background of COPD(?).  Also evidence for new RLL and LLL
   (retrocardiac) infiltrates, concerning for pneumonai (VAP) -->
   empirical antimicrobials.  Continue mechanical ventilation, montior
   ABG.  Monitor sputum, await culture.  Hope to eventually work towards
   SBT and extubation once completes VAP treatment and completes chemoRx
   and XRT.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES -- RLL  --> attributed to VAP.  Now on
   antimicrobials.  Monitor.  LLL infiltrate resolved over past 24 hrs,
   suspect related to mucus plug and /or atalectasis.
   MENTAL STATUS
 very slow to awken, now off Propofol >24 hrs.  Repeat
   head CT unrevealing for new pathology.  MRI not possible due to
   presence of intracranial surgical clips.  Underlying seizure disorder
   (on kepra) --> await EEG interpretation.   LP for CSF analysis (concern
   for carcinomatous meningitis).  Consider Neurological Consultation.
   [**Month (only) 11**] be toxic metabolic.
   SVC SYNDROME -- much improved over past 48 hrs.  Completed
   chemotherapy, continue XRT.
   SMALL CELL CA -- demonstating clinical response to XRT and
   chemotherapy.   Radiation Oncology and Oncology services involve
   appreciate recommendations and guidance.  Monitor for tumor lysis.
   Need to better define prognosis.  Plan repeat Chest CT to assess
   influence of XRT and chemotherapy on tumor mass.
   RIGHT PLEURAL EFFUSION -- resolved, s/p chest tube drainage.
   Malignant.  Chest tube now removed.
   RIGHT PNEUMOTHORAX -- chest tube remains in place, lung fully
   expanded.  No evidence for air leak.
   PERICARDIAL EFFUSION -- no evidence of tamponade on exam
 continue to
   monitor.
   HYPONATREMIA -- improved.  Attributed to adrenal insufficiency,
   hypaldosteronism, SIADH --> possibly a mixture.  Continue steroids.
   HYPERTENSION
 monitor BP.  Maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg
   FLUIDS -- positive fluid balance, likely related to chemotherapy
   agents.  However, appears pre-renal --> continue net hydration.
   Monitor I/O.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to partial compression of the superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise, and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
2. Multifactorial respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube (ETT), extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, and underlying COPD.
3. Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, which are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Mental status: The patient is very slow to awaken and is off propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT scan was unrevealing for new pathology, and an MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. The patient has an underlying seizure disorder and is awaiting EEG interpretation.
5. SVC syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome has improved significantly over the past 48 hours, and chemotherapy has been completed.
6. Small cell carcinoma: The patient has demonstrated a clinical response to radiation therapy (XRT) and chemotherapy.
7. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is being monitored, and the goal is to maintain a systolic blood pressure of 140-160 mmHg.
8. Fluid balance: The patient has a positive fluid balance, likely related to chemotherapy agents, and is at risk for fluid overload.
9. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is rising, and urine output is decreasing, suggesting possible pre-renal or chemotherapy-related acute kidney injury.
10. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has persistent metabolic acidosis with a positive anion gap, attributed to acute renal failure and acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
11. Seizure disorder: The patient is being treated with kepra, and an EEG is planned to assess for non-convulsive status.
12. Sinus dysrhythmia: The patient has sinus pauses, but no hemodynamic compromise, possibly related to the hilar mass or vagal tone.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further respiratory failure or deterioration in lung function.
2. Pneumonia or other respiratory infections.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
4. Renal failure or acute kidney injury.
5. Metabolic acidosis or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Seizure activity or status epilepticus.
7. Infection or sepsis.
8. Tumor lysis syndrome or electrolyte imbalances related to chemotherapy.
9. Adrenal insufficiency or hypoadrenalism.
10. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia related to insulin or glucose therapy.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a history of COPD and recent chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The patient has developed respiratory infiltrates, including RLL and LLL infiltrates, which are attributed to VAP. He also has a history of seizure disorder and is being treated with kepra. The patient has been diagnosed with hypotension, hypocalcemia, and metabolic acidosis, and is at risk for renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, and he is at risk for further deterioration due to malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube, underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, and new RLL and LLL infiltrates.
2. VAP: The patient has developed RLL and LLL infiltrates, which are attributed to VAP. He is at risk for further progression of the infection and potential sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient has developed rising creatinine and falling urine output, which may be related to chemotherapy and recent contrast dye. He is at risk for further deterioration in renal function.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has persistent metabolic acidosis, which may be related to acute renal failure and ATN. He is at risk for further deterioration in acid-base balance.
5. Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of seizure disorder and is being treated with kepra. He is at risk for further seizures and potential status epilepticus.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient has hypocalcemia, which may be related to chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He is at risk for further deterioration in calcium levels.
7. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which may be related to adrenal insufficiency, hypoadrenalism, and SIADH. He is at risk for further deterioration in blood pressure.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He is at risk for further deterioration in hemoglobin levels.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor ABG.
2. Monitor sputum and await culture results.
3. Continue antimicrobials for VAP.
4. Monitor urine output and creatinine levels.
5. Continue kepra for seizure disorder.
6. Monitor electrolytes and calcium levels.
7. Hold beta-blocker for sinus dysrhythmia.
8. Consider cardiology consultation for sinus dysrhythmia.
9. Monitor for tumor lysis and define prognosis.
10. Continue nutritional support with TF.
11. Monitor for fluid overload and adjust fluid management accordingly.
12. Consider neurological consultation for seizure disorder.
13. Continue steroids for adrenal insufficiency.
14. Monitor for further development of respiratory infiltrates and potential sepsis.
15. Consider radiation oncology and oncology services for further guidance on treatment.
