   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy and chemotherapy, now with respiratory failure,
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt still acidotic with RR 28
 little
   room to increase RR. Numerous changes made to ventilator and tube
   placement yesterday.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR. Also with b/l pleural effusions seen on CT although tumor has
   decreased.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated (therapeutic today); will check
   level in AM and readjust dose as needed
 continue holding today (d1 =
   [**2172-8-31**]; 8 day course)
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy; scheduled for formal planning for XRT
   early next week (approx [**2172-9-8**])
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol >48h and still
   not moving extremities or grossly following commands. Most likley toxic
   metabolic encephalopathy as pt is uremic. Differential includes seizure
   although EEG does not demonstrate seizure activity. LP does not
   demonstrate infection or spread of malignancy. CT head negative for
   acute process.
   - f/u  CSF studies
   - Consider neuro consult
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Urine
   casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize SBP 120s-130s.- - gently
   hydrate with IVFs
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Unable to increase RR due to concern for autopeeping in
   setting of possible COPD. Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo and renal recs
   - continue on Bicitra
   - If pH continues to decrease below 7.2, will need bicarb
   .
   # Tachycardia/Hypotension
 Pt with continued tachycardia and episodes
   of hypotension. DDx includes possible enlarging pericardial
   effusion/tamponade (pulsus not helpful in setting of intubation per
   earlier cardiology note), pneumothorax. Pt appears to be in A-fib on
   monitor but difficult to tell. PE likely given malignancy and prolonged
   bed rest but unable to do CTA given renal failure and VQ scan not
   helpful in setting of lung changes.
   -CXR
   -EKG to evaluate for A-fib
   -Fluids to give preload for hypotensive episodes
   -Cardiology consult for STAT echo
   -LENI
s as unable to directly assess for PE
   -t/b with Hem/Onc re: anti-coagulation given tumor treatment
   .
   #. Electrolyte disturbances: Pt now with hypernatremia most likley due
   to dehydration with free water deficit of 1.4L, started on D5W
   overnight. Pt had hyponatremia and hyperkalemia on admission, both
   resolved. Unclear etiology of electrolyte disturbances on admission-
   thought to be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now
   discarded) or possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal
   recommends rechecking urine lytes with saline load, not yet done in
   setting of pt
s other medical issues.  (In SIADH, UNa should increase
   and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   -F/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] and renin
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
 per Hem/Onc, decreased WBC ct
   in setting of neupogen does not bode well.
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - continue neutropenic precautions
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission. Per family, pt did not have SVC syndrome when she came to
   hospital ([**Hospital Unit Name 10**] team thought she had it on presentation to ED). SVC
   syndrome occurred after Y-stent placed. Possible that tumor pushing
   into trachea shifted to compress SVC after stent placement.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   -F/u Hem/Onc recs
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**]. Had new episdoes, again with turning.  Cardiology
   consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency
   and duration on their own without intervention.
   - Care with turning patient
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - Per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   .
   #Leukopenia/thrombocytopenia
 most likely due to chemotherapy. Pt on
   neupogen with continued decreased counts. Per Onc, this does not bode
   well for prognosis. Low suspicion for HITT.
   -F/u hem/onc recs
   -Trend CBC
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   .
   #. Hypertension: Now hypotensive (see above). Metoprolol d/c
d held in
   setting of pauses given concern for beta blocker toxicity. -Continue
   holding metoprolol
   -D/c hydralazine as pt is hypotensive
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   .
   #Goals of care: discuss with family that pt is in multisystem organ
   failure and prognosis is poor.
   ICU Care

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a complex medical history, including small cell lung carcinoma, SVC syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and pleural effusions. She has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, renal failure, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure, acidotic, with a pH of 7.16, and a respiratory rate of 28. She has undergone numerous changes to her ventilator settings and tube placement.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, hypotension, and possible tamponade or pneumothorax. Her cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and her blood pressure is 81/48 mmHg.
* Neurological: Altered mental status, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8, and a possible toxic metabolic encephalopathy. She has a low serum albumin level, which may contribute to her metabolic acidosis.
* Renal: Acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL, and a urine output of 1,075 mL.
* Hematological: Leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and anemia.
* Infectious: Possible pulmonary infection, with a respiratory culture pending.
* Gastrointestinal: Possible stress ulceration, with a pantoprazole IV infusion.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and hypoxemia.
* Cardiovascular instability: Hypotension, tachycardia, and possible cardiac tamponade or pneumothorax.
* Neurological deterioration: Further decline in mental status, seizures, and possible cerebral edema.
* Renal failure: Progressive decline in renal function, electrolyte disturbances, and possible need for dialysis.
* Hematological complications: Bleeding diathesis, infection, and possible need for transfusions.
* Infectious complications: Sepsis, pneumonia, and possible need for antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal complications: Stress ulceration, bleeding, and possible need for endoscopy.

The patient's goals of care should be discussed with her family, taking into account her poor prognosis and multisystem organ failure. The ICU care plan should focus on managing her respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, renal, and hematological complications, while also addressing her nutritional and glycemic control needs.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

1. Respiratory status: The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure with persistent acidosis, requiring high RR and FiO2. There is concern for underlying COPD, possible VAP, and atelectasis/consolidation at bilateral bases.
2. Cardiovascular status: The patient has tachycardia and episodes of hypotension, with new onset A-fib on EKG. The patient has incomplete occlusion of the superior vena cava (SVC) and near complete occlusion of the brachiocephalic veins, which may be contributing to her hypotension.
3. Neurological status: The patient has altered mental status, with no movement or gross following of commands. The differential diagnosis includes toxic metabolic encephalopathy, seizure disorder, and possible SIADH.
4. Renal status: The patient has acute renal failure, with anuria and increased uric acid levels. The patient is volume overloaded, making it difficult to administer fluids.
5. Hematological status: The patient has leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, likely due to chemotherapy. The patient is on neupogen, but the counts continue to decrease.
6. Infectious status: The patient has a possible VAP, with bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis/consolidation at bilateral bases. The patient has a history of small cell lung carcinoma and is receiving chemotherapy.
7. Metabolic status: The patient has metabolic acidosis, with a pH of 7.16. The patient has hypernatremia, which has resolved, and hyperkalemia, which has also resolved.
8. Electrolyte disturbances: The patient has electrolyte disturbances, including hyponatremia and hyperkalemia on admission, which have resolved.
9. Small cell lung carcinoma: The patient has a diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma, which is likely to be malignant.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and further deterioration may occur.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, leading to further electrolyte disturbances and acidosis.
4. Infections: The patient has a possible VAP, and further infections may develop.
5. Hematological complications: The patient's leukopenia and thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding or infection.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction.
7. Small cell lung carcinoma progression: The patient's small cell lung carcinoma may progress, leading to further organ failure and death.

Based on this information, the patient's goals of care should be discussed with the family, and a palliative care consult should be considered. The patient's code status should be DNR, and the disposition should be ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo f with respiratory failure in setting of newly diagnosed lung ca
   (likely small cell) c/b SVC syndrome (partial compression), airway
   compromise (requiring Y-stent) admitted for xrt and chemotherapy now
   with progressive clinical decline and MODS.
   Issues include:
          Resp failure
          Large lung mass (likely small cell), airway collapse, R
   effusion
          Svc syndrome
          R pnx (CT in palce with lung reinflated)
          VAP
          Decreased level of consciousness/unresponsiveness off
   sedation
          Tachycardia
atrial fib
          Hypotension
          ARF
          Thrombocytopenia/pancytopenia
          Hypernatremia (resolved)
   Pt is in MODS with underlying aggressive lung malignancy  and shows
   continued clinical decline.  Her prognosis is extremely poor.  We
   continue to update family regarding worsening status and to address
   goals of care who fully understand her critical condition.
   Pt
s respiratory failure is multifactorial, [**2-10**]
   malpositioning/migration of ETT between stent and tracheal wall,
   extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi [**2-10**]
   lung mass, probable underlying COPD, and RLL and LLL (retrocardiac)
   infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (VAP), plugging.  She remains
   tachy in afib and hypotensive.  At this time we are limited as to
   options to further temporize.  Giving additional fluids is contributing
   to volume overload with third spacing and tense abd distention in
   setting of progressive renal decline (progressively anuric), further
   impacting her resp status, now with increasing O2 needs and high airway
   presssures.  She remains unresponsive off sedation X days, likely toxic
   metabolic from uremia and infection.  Work up with eeg, LP, and head ct
   has been unrevealing.
   --We will stop fluids and compensate as able with vent.
   --We will check bladder pressures for compartment syndome
   --Dialysis would further prolong course in this patient and is unlikely
   to change to her overall prognosis.
   --Continue ACV support.  We will decrease her TV to lower pips/plts and
   accept ph > 7.2, Decrease fio2 and accept pao2 > 65.
    --We have discussed and evaluated for a broad ddx of her a-fib and
   hypotension (including infection, tension PTX, PE, rv compression from
   mass/decreasing CO and preload from mass, cardiac tamponade and cardiac
   ischemia).   This appears mutlifactorial and largely related to
   underlying infection and lung mass.
   -- We continue empiric antiibx (vanco,cipro,cef).
   Remainder as per resident note.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2172-9-5**] 03:41 AM 10 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2172-8-26**] 01:00 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2172-8-26**] 03:37 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots(Systemic anticoagulation: sq hep held for low plts)
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 40 minutes
   Patient is critically ill
   Addendum
   Following am rounds, I spoke with pt
s son by phone and updated him as
   to his mother
s condition and continued decline. Explained that we are
   very limited as additional fluids are contributing to worsening
   oxygenation and significant volume overload in setting of progressive
   renal failure.  Without fluids, she is becoming progressively
   hypotensive.  We are now maxing out in terms of ventilator on 100%
   FIO2.   She remains unresponsive off all sedation. Her prognosis for
   recovery remains extremely poor and she is declining despite our
   aggressive attempts.  Pt
s son expressed his full understanding.  All
   of his questions were answered.  At this time he wishes to move toward
   CMO with terminal extubation understanding that his mother will likely
   pass quickly after removal of the ETT.  We will focus fully on her
   comfort with morphine as needed.  His uncle is headed in and he will
   let us know if his uncle wishes to be present at the time of
   extubation.  He and pt
s sisters and other family member spent time at
   bedside yesterday and do not plan to be present.
   Additional 20 minutes crit care time spent in discussion.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to a large compressing lung cancer, likely small cell, and SVC syndrome. She has a history of newly diagnosed lung cancer, airway compromise, and is admitted for radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The patient has developed atrial fibrillation, hypotension, and is in multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). Her prognosis is extremely poor.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including malpositioning of the endotracheal tube, extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, and probable underlying COPD. She remains tachycardic in atrial fibrillation and hypotensive.

The patient's condition is critical, and the medical team is limited in their options to temporize her condition. Fluid administration is contributing to volume overload and tense abdominal distension, further impacting her respiratory status. The patient remains unresponsive off sedation and is likely toxic from uremia and infection.

The plan is to stop fluids and compensate as able with the ventilator, check bladder pressures for compartment syndrome, and continue ACV support. The patient's TV will be decreased to lower pips and plts, and her FIO2 will be decreased to accept a PaO2 of 65.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, and further deterioration is likely.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia in atrial fibrillation increase the risk of cardiac complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's progressive anuria and increasing creatinine levels indicate worsening renal function, which may lead to further complications.
4. Infection: The patient's ongoing infection and sepsis syndrome increase the risk of further complications, including septic shock and multi-organ failure.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of DVT and SVC syndrome increase the risk of pulmonary embolism.
6. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion and SVC syndrome increase the risk of cardiac tamponade.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness increase the risk of neurological complications, including seizures and cerebral edema.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive management of the patient's respiratory failure, including optimization of ventilation and oxygenation.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability closely and consider vasopressor support if necessary.
3. Continue renal replacement therapy to manage the patient's progressive renal failure.
4. Continue antimicrobial therapy to manage the patient's ongoing infection.
5. Monitor the patient's coagulation profile and consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic complications.
6. Consider echocardiography to evaluate the patient's cardiac function and rule out cardiac tamponade.
7. Consider neurological consultation to evaluate the patient's neurological status and potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to small cell lung cancer, airway compromise, and right-sided effusion. She has a complex medical history, including SVC syndrome, pneumonia, and altered mental status. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a high level of oxygenation. Her condition has been deteriorating, with worsening respiratory failure, hypotension, and decreased urine output.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube, extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, and probable underlying COPD.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has multifocal pneumonia and post-obstructive pneumonia, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
3. Hypercapnia: The patient's pH is elevated, indicating hypercapnia, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to her underlying lung disease, sepsis, and dehydration.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's urine output is decreasing, and she has evidence of muddy brown casts on her urinalysis, which suggests AKI.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may be due to her underlying lung disease, sepsis, and chemotherapy.
7. Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, which may be due to her underlying lung disease, sepsis, and chemotherapy.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an elevated potassium level, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
9. Fluid overload: The patient has a high fluid balance, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure and AKI.
10. Sepsis: The patient has a high level of suspicion for sepsis, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure and AKI.

The patient's prognosis is poor, and she is unlikely to recover from her underlying lung disease and sepsis. The team is focusing on providing supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, and managing her symptoms to improve her quality of life.
